moves.1. f4 b6: I've been experimenting with a universal b6 defense.  This is the first time that I faced f4.
moves.2. d4: This, I thought, was unusual.  b6 tries to control the light squares with the B and d4 just creates a light-square hole on e4.
moves.2... Bb7 3. e3 e6 4. Nf3 Nf6 5. Nc3 Bb4: Dropping the N into the light-square hole.
moves.9. Bb4 d6 10. O-O Nd7 11. c4 f5: Supporting the N further, while keeping the diagonal open for the B.
moves.14. Ng5: This surprised me.  While Ng5 does go after Black's weakness on e3, I would have thought more preparation was needed, like Rc1, b4, c5 etc.
moves.14... Nxg5 15. Bxg5 Qg6 16. Be2: I'm not sure of White's intention here.  Even without Be2, Ng4 can be met easily.  Maybe Bf3 was the eventual intent?
moves.16... h6: White will now lose material as the B is pinned against a mating square g2.
moves.17. Bxf6: White blunders and misses the tactic.
moves.17... Qxg2#: White had more space and the ability to attack Black's pawn structure.  I think that was what was called for, rather than a direct Kingside attack.
